awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Representation Varieties, Representation Homology, and Applications in Algebra, Geometry, and Topology
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum models are playing an increasingly important role in physics and other natural sciences. Geometric spaces that parametrize approximations of quantum objects by matrices are therefore an important tool in the study of several models of natural phenomena. Not surprisingly, these spaces play a crucial role in several areas of mathematics and mathematical physics. Unfortunately, such spaces are often difficult to study since they are usually not smooth enough. Intuitively speaking, this means that they have too many edges and corners.  This project is centered on a tool that refines these spaces in a way that appears to overcome many of these difficulties. The work is anticipated to lead to new insights into several questions where such spaces play a role. It also unifies several research areas by focusing on applications of this tool in different parts of mathematics, in addition to further developing this tool as an end in itself. 

In earlier work, the investigators constructed a derived version of representation varieties of associative algebras by extending the representation functor to differential graded (DG) algebras and deriving it in the sense of non-abelian homological algebra. This gives a new homology theory for algebras, called representation homology. This project aims to give a new construction of representation homology of associative algebras in terms of classical (abelian) homological algebra and also extend it to other structures of topological nature. This should lead to various applications in geometry and topology and open the way to efficient computations. A number of precise conjectures regarding the structure of representation homology of classical spaces will be investigated. In addition, the investigators will attack some well-known hard problems in representation theory (such as the strong MacDonald conjecture) using new topological methods.

por.por_cntn:
The complexity of fundamental objects in nature studied by physics, life sciences and engineering stems from their nonlinearity.
Developing tools and exact quantitative methods for describing such objects is one of the basic problems of mathematics. Representation theory
is part of mathematics that studies linear approximations -- called representations -- of nonlinear objects that arise in physics and geometry
(such as symmetry groups of physical theories and fundamental groups of geometric spaces). The totality of all such representations -- called a representation variety -- is a fundamental invariant of a nonlinear object that carries a lot of useful information and plays a role in many areas of
mathematics and theoretical physics. Representation varieties have, however, several serious deficiencies that make it hard to understand their
properties and as a result, restrict the scope of their applications. First of all, they usually possess `bad singularities' that one needs to
remove: this often requires the use of highly sophisticated geometric machinery called resolution of singularities. Second, the representation varieties are only defined for representations of `rigid' algebraic objects, such as groups and associative algebras; they are not quite suitable for classifying more `flexible' objects such as geometric spaces defined up to continuous deformations (homotopy types). Third, representation varieties are notoriously hard to describe explicitly, even in simplest examples: they are not quite adapted for symbolic computations using standard computer algebra software.
The main goal of this project was to remedy these theoretical problems by introducing a more general, more flexible and (in a sense) more natural
object that refines the classical notion of representation variety. This new mathematical object called representation homology has already found a number of interesting and important applications in different parts of mathematics, especially in topology and representation theory. Some of the principal mathematical results of the present project include the establishing of a fundamental relation between representation varieties --- in the form of representation homology -- and higher Hochschild homology as well as an explicit computation of representation homology of an arbitrary simply connected topological space over the rational numbers in terms of its classical algebraic models. Another output of this project, not less important, is a list of concrete and carefully stated conjectures regarding the behavior of representation varieties and representation homology of Riemann surfaces and three-dimensional manifolds. Clarifying (proving or disproving) these conjectures should lead to a deeper understanding of these fundamental geometric objects, and potentially will result in new applications in physics and sciences. Some of our conjectures have been recently proved by several groups of researchers working in representation theory.
